text: My belief is that, like any domain or industry, the more it matters, the more the design matters. What happens is whenever there's a new paradigm, I don't know, like the mobile or the web or something the first iterations of those products existing there, they don't have to be super well designed necessarily because they are the first. Then, as you build the 100,000 different email clients, any email client now has to be pretty good to be even considered an email client. It's like the bar is so high.
speaker: Karri Saarinen
context: Lenny asks Karri about when design can be enough of a differentiator against incumbents and whether founders should invest heavily in design versus other areas like distribution or technology. Karri explains his theory about how design becomes increasingly important as markets mature and become more crowded. He argues that in new paradigms like mobile or web, early products don't need great design since they're first to market, but as competition increases, the design bar rises significantly.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 어떤 분야나 산업이든 영향력이 클수록 디자인이 더 중요해요. 새로운 패러다임(paradigm)이 등장하면, 예를 들어 모바일(mobile)이나 웹(web)처럼 처음 나오는 제품들은 꼭 디자인이 완벽할 필요가 없어요 — 처음이니까요. 그런데 제품들이 쌓여서 이메일 클라이언트(email client)가 10만 개쯤 되면, 이제는 '이게 이메일 클라이언트로 인정받으려면' 꽤 잘 만들어져야 해요. 기준이 정말 높아지거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得吧，不管什么领域或者行业，越重要的东西，设计就越重要。一般来说，每当出现新的技术变革，比如移动互联网啊、web啊什么的，第一批产品其实不用设计得特别好，因为它们是第一个吃螃蟹的嘛。但是等到市面上有了十万个不同的邮箱客户端之后，现在随便哪个邮箱客户端都得做得相当不错，才能让人觉得这是个像样的邮箱。就是门槛已经被抬得特别高了。
text_es: Mi punto de vista es que, como en cualquier sector o industria, mientras más importante sea, más importa el diseño. Lo que pasa es que cada vez que surge un nuevo paradigma, no sé, como el móvil o la web o algo así, las primeras versiones de esos productos que aparecen no necesariamente tienen que estar súper bien diseñados porque son los primeros. Después, cuando ya tienes 100,000 clientes de email diferentes, cualquier cliente de email ahora tiene que estar bastante bueno para que siquiera lo consideren un cliente de email. Es como que el listón está altísimo.

text: I think today it's almost a very basic thing now. Pretty much from the very beginning, you need pretty high level design for people to even pay attention or consider you seriously. And I think it's not necessarily fair because sometimes it's like maybe the product is really good but they didn't have a designer or they didn't have time to do it and then people just dismiss it because it doesn't seem like something that they interest them.
speaker: Karri Saarinen
context: Karri continues explaining why design has become crucial for modern startups. He points out that unlike older companies like Google or YouTube that launched with very basic websites, today's startups need high-quality design from day one just to get noticed. He acknowledges this creates an unfair barrier where good products might be dismissed simply due to poor visual design, even when the underlying functionality is solid.
text_ko: 요즘에는 그게 거의 기본이에요. 처음부터 사람들한테 주목받거나 진지하게 고려되려면 꽤 높은 수준의 하이레벨 디자인(high-level design)이 필요해요. 꼭 공평하다고는 할 수 없는데, 제품이 정말 좋은데도 디자이너가 없거나 디자인할 시간이 없어서 사람들이 관심을 안 가지면 그냥 무시당하곤 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在这基本上已经成了标配了。几乎从一开始，你就得有很高水准的设计，别人才会关注你，才会认真考虑你的产品。我觉得这不一定公平，因为有时候可能产品本身真的很不错，但他们没有设计师，或者没时间去做设计，结果大家就因为看起来不怎么样就直接pass了，觉得没什么意思。
text_es: Creo que hoy en día es algo súper básico ya. Prácticamente desde el inicio, necesitas un diseño de muy alto nivel para que la gente te haga caso o te tome en serio. Y pienso que no necesariamente es justo porque a veces puede ser que el producto esté padrísimo pero no tuvieron diseñador o no tuvieron tiempo para trabajarlo bien y entonces la gente lo descarta porque no parece algo que les llame la atención.

text: So I think similarly, with startups or SaaS, it's like your landing page or some of the other things. It's like they are already communicating something to the user and they're setting the expectations and then I think that that can be very useful thing, especially early on when no one really knows you or knows the product or cares about you. So I think especially, I feel like design can be very good leverage in the beginning.
speaker: Karri Saarinen
context: Karri draws an analogy between product packaging (like Apple's attention to unboxing experiences) and startup design elements like landing pages. He explains that design serves as the first impression that sets user expectations before they even try the product. This is particularly valuable for unknown startups that need to establish credibility and quality perception from the first interaction, making design a powerful form of leverage in the early stages.
text_ko: 저도 비슷하게 생각해요. 스타트업(startups)이나 서비스형 소프트웨어(SaaS)에서는 랜딩 페이지(landing page)나 다른 몇 가지 요소들이 이미 사용자에게 무언가를 전달하고 기대치를 설정해요. 특히 아무도 아직 당신이나 제품을 잘 모르고 관심도 없을 초반에는 그게 훨씬 더 유용할 수 있어요. 그래서 저는 초반에 디자인이 정말 큰 레버리지(leverage)가 된다고 느껴요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得创业公司或者SaaS产品也是一样的道理，比如你的落地页(landing page)或者其他一些东西，它们其实已经在跟用户沟通了，在给用户设定期望值。我觉得这个特别有用，尤其是在早期阶段，那时候没人知道你是谁，不了解你的产品，也不关心你。所以我觉得设计在一开始的时候真的可以起到四两拨千斤的作用。
text_es: Entonces creo que pasa algo parecido con las startups o SaaS, es como tu página de aterrizaje (landing page) o algunas de las otras cosas. Es como que ya le están comunicando algo al usuario y están creando expectativas, y creo que eso puede ser súper útil, sobre todo al principio cuando nadie te conoce realmente o conoce el producto o le importas. Entonces creo que especialmente, siento que el diseño puede ser una palanca muy poderosa desde el comienzo.

text: So for every project there's a project lead. That lead can be engineer or designer. It's not a formal role or it's not based on your whatever level or it's just like you need to be certain title that you can be that. It's more like an assignment that now you are responsible getting the project started and working together with the team, figuring it out, and then communicating changes or communicating how that progress happens.
speaker: Karri Saarinen
context: Lenny asks how Linear functions with only one product manager across the entire company. Karri explains their project-based leadership model where engineers and designers take turns being project leads. This isn't a formal hierarchy based on seniority or titles, but rather a rotating assignment system where someone takes responsibility for driving a specific project forward, coordinating with the team, and managing communications about progress.
text_ko: 그래서 모든 프로젝트에는 프로젝트 리드(project lead)가 있어요. 그 리드는 엔지니어나 디자이너일 수도 있어요. 이건 정식 직책이나 직급에 따라 정해지는 게 아니고, 꼭 특정 직함을 가져야만 맡을 수 있는 역할도 아니에요. 좀 더 정확히 말하면, 프로젝트를 시작하고 팀과 함께 방향을 잡아가며 문제를 해결하고, 진행 상황이나 변경 사항을 팀에 공유하는 책임을 맡는 배정이에요.
text_zh: 所以每个项目都有一个项目负责人(project lead)。这个负责人可以是工程师，也可以是设计师。这不是什么正式的职位，也不是看你什么级别，更不是说你必须有某个头衔才能当。就是个分工安排，现在你要负责把项目启动起来，跟团队一起合作，把事情搞定，然后有什么变化或者进展都要及时沟通。
text_es: Entonces para cada proyecto hay un líder de proyecto. Ese líder puede ser un ingeniero o un diseñador. No es un rol formal ni se basa en tu nivel o que necesites tener cierto título para poder serlo. Es más bien una asignación donde ahora tú eres el responsable de arrancar el proyecto y trabajar junto con el equipo, ir resolviendo las cosas sobre la marcha, y luego comunicar los cambios o comunicar cómo va avanzando todo.

text: I think sometimes people use data a lot or too much because they're worrying or they're afraid that, will I make the wrong choice? And I'm using data to make the choice for me. But then you might still feel like this is not the right choice, but the data is telling me is the right choice and then turns out maybe it was the right choice or not. But at least we made that choice and the data didn't make that choice for us.
speaker: Karri Saarinen
context: Lenny asks about Linear's approach of not using metrics-based goals or A/B testing, which differs from many other companies. Karri explains his philosophy that over-reliance on data often stems from fear of making wrong decisions. He argues that leaders should make decisions based on customer understanding and intuition rather than letting data make choices for them, emphasizing the importance of taking ownership of decisions rather than hiding behind metrics.
text_ko: 가끔 사람들은 실수할까 봐, 잘못된 선택을 할까 봐 걱정해서 데이터(data)를 과하게 쓰는 것 같아요. 데이터를 통해 대신 선택해 주길 바라는 거죠. 그런데도 마음속으로는 '이게 진짜 맞는 선택일까' 하는 불안이 남을 수 있고, 데이터가 이게 맞다고 말해도 실제로는 맞을 수도 있고 아닐 수도 있어요. 그래도 적어도 그 선택은 우리가 한 거고, 데이터가 대신 한 건 아니에요.
text_zh: 我觉得有时候大家过度依赖数据，其实是因为担心害怕——怕做错决定对吧？就想着让数据来替我做选择。但问题是，即使数据显示这个选择是对的，你心里可能还是觉得不太对劲。最后不管结果怎么样，至少这个决定是我们自己做的，而不是被数据牵着鼻子走。
text_es: Creo que a veces la gente usa demasiados datos porque tiene miedo de equivocarse, ¿no? Como que dicen "ay, ¿y si tomo la decisión equivocada?" Entonces usan los datos para que básicamente los datos decidan por ellos. Pero después te puedes quedar con esa sensación de que no es la decisión correcta, aunque los datos te digan que sí lo es. Al final puede que haya sido la decisión acertada o no, pero lo importante es que nosotros tomamos esa decisión - no dejamos que los datos decidieran por nosotros.

text: I think there's always things that you're supposed to do or it sounds like a good idea to do. And it could be like, yeah, come to this podcast. And I actually think before it wasn't like... Or I always have this question, is this important to do now or is it important to maybe do later? So I think, for example, the question on this podcast is I didn't feel like it was important to do it earlier because we weren't at the stage or a scale or something that I think it'd be as interesting or something.
speaker: Karri Saarinen
context: Lenny asks Karri about his exceptional focus and ability to avoid distractions, noting how difficult it was to get him on the podcast initially. Karri shares his decision-making framework for maintaining focus, explaining that he constantly evaluates whether activities are important to do now versus later. He uses the podcast example to illustrate how he delayed this interview until Linear reached a stage where the conversation would be more valuable and interesting.
text_ko: 항상 해야 할 일들이 있거나 그냥 좋은 생각처럼 들리는 일들이 있는 것 같아요. 예를 들어 '이 팟캐스트(podcast)에 나오면 좋겠다' 하는 얘기일 수도 있고요. 사실 전에는 꼭 그렇지 않았던 것 같아요. 저는 늘 '이걸 지금 하는 게 중요한가, 아니면 나중에 하는 게 더 나을까?'라는 질문을 해요. 그래서 이 팟캐스트의 경우를 예로 들면, 저는 예전에는 굳이 더 일찍 할 필요가 있다고 느끼지 않았어요. 그때는 우리가 아직 그런 단계에 있지 않았고 규모(scale)도 그만큼 크지 않아서 지금만큼 흥미롭지 않았을 거라고 생각했거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得总有一些事情，要么是你应该做的，要么听起来是个好主意。比如说，来参加这个播客。其实我以前不是这样想的...我总是在想一个问题，这件事是现在做重要，还是以后再做比较重要？拿这个播客来说吧，我之前觉得没必要这么早来做，因为我们还没到那个阶段，规模也不够，感觉不会那么有意思。
text_es: Creo que siempre hay cosas que se supone que debes hacer o que suenan como buena idea hacer. Y puede ser algo como, sí, ve a este podcast. Y la verdad es que antes no era como... O siempre me hago esta pregunta: ¿es importante hacer esto ahora o es importante hacerlo más adelante? Entonces creo que, por ejemplo, con el tema de este podcast, no sentía que fuera importante hacerlo antes porque no estábamos en la etapa o el nivel donde creo que hubiera sido tan interesante o algo así.
